title: 29 CFR 1910.132 – General Requirements for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)
summary: Employers must provide and enforce the use of appropriate PPE whenever workplace hazards could cause injury or impairment.
key_requirements: Provide appropriate PPE (hard hats, safety glasses, gloves, ear protection) for workplace hazards
Conduct hazard assessment to determine needed PPE
Ensure PPE properly fits each exposed employee
Train workers on when PPE is necessary, how to wear and adjust it, its limitations, and proper care
Remove defective or damaged PPE from service
importance: PPE is the last line of defense against injuries. This standard ensures workers have gear to minimize exposure to hazards when other controls cannot fully eliminate risks, preventing serious injuries to eyes, head, hands, and more.

title: 29 CFR 1926.416 – Electrical Wiring and Cord Safety (Construction)
summary: Prohibits damaged or improper electrical cords and emphasizes good housekeeping with cords to prevent electrical hazards and tripping.
key_requirements: Prohibit damaged or frayed electric cords
Do not fasten extension cords with staples, hang from nails, or suspend by wire
Keep temporary cables out of walkways or properly cover/tape them if crossing aisles
Prevent cords from running through doorways or across floors where they can be pinched
Maintain good housekeeping to prevent tripping hazards and cord damage
importance: Improperly maintained or positioned electrical wires pose multiple hazards including electric shocks, burns, fires, and tripping accidents. This standard prevents common electrical accidents by ensuring cords are in safe condition and properly managed.

title: 29 CFR 1910.176 – Handling Materials (Clear Aisles and Passageways)
summary: Requires aisles and walkways to be kept clear and unobstructed to prevent slips, trips, and collisions.
key_requirements: Maintain sufficient safe clearances for aisles
Keep passageways in good repair with no obstructions
Clearly mark permanent aisles
Prohibit storage or clutter that blocks walkways
Implement good housekeeping practices (clean spills, remove loose objects)
importance: Clear, unobstructed aisles are critical for preventing slips, trips, and collisions in everyday operations. Cluttered pathways can hinder emergency evacuations and frequently lead to workplace falls and injuries.

title: 29 CFR 1910.37 – Maintenance of Exit Routes (Emergency Egress)
summary: Ensures exit routes remain free and unobstructed at all times for safe emergency evacuation.
key_requirements: Keep exit routes free and unobstructed at all times
Prohibit materials, equipment, or storage in exit paths
Keep corridors, stairwells, and doorways clear of blockages
Ensure exit doors cannot be locked from inside
Allow employees to open exit doors without special knowledge or tools
Properly mark exit routes leading to safe refuge or outside
importance: Blocked or locked exits can be deadly in fires or other emergencies. This standard is crucial for fire safety and emergency planning, ensuring everyone can evacuate quickly and safely when every second counts.

title: 29 CFR 1926.300 – Hand and Power Tools (General Requirements)
summary: Requires tools to be kept in safe condition with proper maintenance and safety guards in place.
key_requirements: Maintain all hand and power tools in safe condition
Conduct regular inspections and maintenance
Replace worn parts and keep blades sharp
Ensure handles are secure
Install required safety guards and devices
Guard exposed moving parts (belts, gears, shafts, blades)
Use appropriate PPE when using tools
importance: Even simple tools can cause severe injuries if defective, poorly maintained, or used without safeguards. This standard addresses one of the most common sources of workplace injuries by ensuring tools are safe to operate and reinforcing regular inspection and hazard awareness.

title: 29 CFR 1910.212 – Machine Guarding (General Requirements for Machines)
summary: Requires machine guarding to protect operators from moving parts and points of operation hazards.
key_requirements: Guard moving parts and points of operation
Protect from point-of-operation contact, ingoing nip points, rotating parts, flying chips, and sparks
Install guards, safety devices, or enclosures on machinery
Ensure guards are affixed to the machine and not easily removable
Design guards to not introduce new hazards
Provide equivalent protection if direct attachment is not feasible
importance: Inadequate machine guarding is consistently among the top OSHA violations. Unguarded machinery can lead to gruesome injuries including crushed limbs, amputations, severe cuts, or death. This standard compels employers to eliminate these risks at the source.

title: 29 CFR 1910.178 – Powered Industrial Trucks (Forklift Safety)
summary: Governs safe design, maintenance, and operation of forklifts and similar industrial trucks with mandatory operator training.
key_requirements: Meet recognized safety standards for vehicle design
Conduct regular inspections and maintenance
Remove unsafe forklifts from service until repaired
Follow safe operating practices (safe speeds, use horns, no extra riders)
Develop comprehensive training program
Ensure operators are trained, evaluated, and certified
Cover both truck-related and workplace-specific topics
Provide refresher training as needed
importance: Forklifts are involved in numerous serious accidents with roughly 100 fatalities and 35,000 serious injuries annually in U.S. workplaces. This comprehensive standard mitigates risks through equipment upkeep and operator competency requirements.

title: 29 CFR 1926.451 – Scaffolds (General Requirements in Construction)
summary: Establishes safety requirements for scaffold construction, support, fall protection, and access in construction work.
key_requirements: Design scaffolds by qualified person to support 4 times maximum intended load
Use proper footings and foundation (base plates, mud sills)
Do not overload platforms beyond capacity
Use materials and components in good condition per manufacturer instructions
Provide fall protection for scaffolds over 10 feet (guardrails or personal fall arrest)
Fully plank and deck scaffold platforms
Install guardrails on all open sides and ends
Provide safe means of access (ladders, stairs, built-in ladder frames)
Inspect scaffolds before each work shift and after incidents
Have competent person oversee erection, moving, and dismantling
importance: Scaffolding hazards are a leading cause of injuries and citations in construction. Scaffold-related accidents account for about 4,500 injuries and over 60 deaths annually. This standard addresses critical aspects of scaffold safety including strength, stability, fall protection, and oversight.

title: 29 CFR 1926.501 – Fall Protection (Duty to Have Fall Protection in Construction)
summary: Requires fall protection for construction workers at elevations of 6 feet or more above lower levels.
key_requirements: Provide fall protection at elevations of 6 feet or more
Install guardrail systems around edges and openings
Provide safety net systems where appropriate
Equip workers with personal fall arrest systems (harnesses with lifelines/anchors)
Protect workers on unprotected roof edges or leading edges
Cover workers near skylights or floor openings
Protect workers on scaffolds and ladders
Cover workers over excavations
Protect workers near dangerous equipment
Provide training on fall hazards and protection equipment
importance: Falls are consistently the number one cause of fatalities in construction, representing roughly one-third of all on-site deaths. This is OSHA's most frequently cited violation. Enforcing fall protection saves lives by preventing deadly falls and significantly improving jobsite safety.

title: 29 CFR 1910.134 – Respiratory Protection
summary: Establishes requirements for respiratory protection programs to protect workers from airborne contaminants and oxygen-deficient atmospheres.
key_requirements: Develop and implement a written respiratory protection program
Conduct workplace evaluation to identify respiratory hazards
Select appropriate respirators based on hazard assessment
Provide medical evaluations for respirator users
Conduct fit testing for tight-fitting respirators
Train employees on proper respirator use and maintenance
Implement procedures for respirator cleaning, storage, and inspection
Establish procedures for respirator use in IDLH (Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health) atmospheres
importance: Respiratory protection is critical for preventing occupational lung diseases and fatalities from airborne hazards. This standard ensures workers have proper protection when engineering controls cannot eliminate respiratory hazards.

title: 29 CFR 1910.147 – The Control of Hazardous Energy (Lockout/Tagout)
summary: Establishes requirements for controlling hazardous energy during servicing and maintenance of machines and equipment.
key_requirements: Develop and implement energy control procedures
Identify all energy sources and isolation points
Use lockout devices to prevent equipment startup
Use tagout devices when lockout is not feasible
Train authorized employees on energy control procedures
Train affected employees on lockout/tagout purpose and use
Conduct periodic inspections of energy control procedures
Ensure only authorized employees perform lockout/tagout
Verify isolation and de-energization before work begins
importance: Lockout/tagout prevents serious injuries and fatalities from unexpected equipment startup or energy release. This standard is essential for protecting maintenance workers from hazardous energy during equipment servicing.

title: 29 CFR 1910.1200 – Hazard Communication Standard
summary: Requires employers to inform employees about hazardous chemicals in the workplace through comprehensive hazard communication programs.
key_requirements: Develop and implement a written hazard communication program
Maintain safety data sheets (SDS) for all hazardous chemicals
Ensure all containers are properly labeled
Provide employee training on chemical hazards and protective measures
Maintain a list of hazardous chemicals in the workplace
Inform employees of non-routine tasks involving hazardous chemicals
Provide information to contractors about hazardous chemicals
Update SDSs when new information becomes available
importance: Hazard communication ensures workers understand chemical risks and protective measures. This standard is crucial for preventing chemical-related injuries and illnesses by providing essential safety information.

title: 29 CFR 1910.146 – Permit-Required Confined Spaces
summary: Establishes requirements for protecting workers from confined space hazards through permit systems and safety procedures.
key_requirements: Identify and evaluate confined spaces in the workplace
Develop and implement a permit-required confined space program
Test atmospheric conditions before entry
Provide appropriate ventilation and monitoring
Ensure rescue and emergency services are available
Train employees on confined space hazards and procedures
Use proper entry permits and procedures
Provide appropriate PPE and rescue equipment
Conduct pre-entry briefings and safety meetings
importance: Confined spaces present unique and often fatal hazards. This standard prevents deaths and injuries by ensuring proper evaluation, testing, and safety procedures before entering confined spaces.

title: 29 CFR 1910.38 – Emergency Action Plans
summary: Requires employers to develop and implement emergency action plans for workplace emergencies.
key_requirements: Develop a written emergency action plan
Establish procedures for reporting emergencies
Create evacuation procedures and routes
Implement procedures for accounting for employees after evacuation
Designate and train emergency response personnel
Establish procedures for employees who remain to operate critical operations
Provide training to all employees on emergency procedures
Review and update the plan as necessary
importance: Emergency action plans provide structured response to workplace emergencies, ensuring employee safety and minimizing injuries during incidents. Proper planning and training save lives during critical situations.

title: 29 CFR 1910.151 – Medical Services and First Aid
summary: Establishes requirements for medical services and first aid availability in the workplace.
key_requirements: Ensure medical personnel are readily available for advice and consultation
Provide first aid training for designated employees
Maintain first aid supplies and equipment
Ensure quick access to medical services
Provide emergency eyewash and shower stations where needed
Establish procedures for medical emergencies
Train employees on first aid procedures
Maintain records of medical services provided
importance: Prompt medical attention can mean the difference between life and death in workplace emergencies. This standard ensures adequate medical services and first aid capabilities are available when needed.

title: 29 CFR 1926.95 – Criteria for Personal Protective Equipment (Construction)
summary: Establishes criteria for personal protective equipment in construction work, requiring employers to provide appropriate PPE at no cost to employees.
key_requirements: Provide appropriate PPE for eyes, face, head, and extremities
Protect against workplace hazards from processes, chemicals, or mechanical irritants
Maintain PPE in sanitary and reliable condition
Ensure PPE is of safe design and construction
Provide PPE at no cost to employees
Ensure proper fit for each affected employee
Train employees on proper use and care of PPE
Remove defective PPE from service
importance: PPE is essential for protecting construction workers from various hazards. This standard ensures workers have appropriate protection and that employers provide PPE at no cost, removing financial barriers to safety.

title: 29 CFR 1926.502 – Fall Protection Systems Criteria and Practices
summary: Establishes criteria and practices for fall protection systems used in construction work.
key_requirements: Install guardrail systems with proper height and strength requirements
Ensure safety net systems meet strength and installation criteria
Use personal fall arrest systems with proper anchorage
Limit maximum arresting force to 1,800 pounds
Prevent free fall distances greater than 6 feet
Inspect fall protection systems before each use
Remove defective components from service
Provide proper training on fall protection systems
importance: Proper fall protection systems are critical for preventing construction fatalities. This standard ensures fall protection equipment meets performance criteria and is properly maintained and used.
